title: How to Cook Ampalaya

steps.headline: Soak the bitter melon in salted water for several minutes.
steps.description: Place 2 pieces of bitter melon that has been cleaned and cut into thin slices into a large bowl. Pour approximately 18 ounces (532 ml) of lukewarm water over the melon to cover it, and sprinkle 2 tablespoons (34 g) of salt into the water. Let the melon soak for about 5 minutes to help remove some of the bitterness.

steps.headline: Squeeze the bitter melon in cheesecloth to drain.
steps.description: After the melon has soaked for several minutes, remove it from the water and place it on a piece of cheesecloth. Wrap the cheesecloth around it, and press on it to remove all of the excess moisture. Set the melon aside for the moment.

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a pan.
steps.description: Place a large skillet on the stove, and heat it on on medium-high. Add 2 tablespoons (45 ml) of cooking oil such as canola, and let it heat in the pan for about 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Cook the onion and garlic for several minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 tablespoon (8 g) of minced garlic and 1 large sliced onion to the heated pan. Allow the garlic and onion to saute until the garlic is golden brown and the onions are translucent, which should take 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Add the tomatoes and saute until they’re softened.
steps.description: Mix 1 large tomato that’s been sliced into the pan with the onion and garlic. Let the tomatoes cook until they soften, which should take about 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Stir in the bitter melon and cook it until tender.
steps.description: Once the tomato is softened, add the drained bitter melon to the pan. Saute it until it softens a bit, which should take approximately 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Pour the eggs over the mixture and cook until partially done.
steps.description: After you’ve cooked the melon for a few minutes, add two beaten eggs to the pan over the melon, garlic, onion, and tomatoes. Let the mixture cook until the eggs are partially done, which should take about 2 to 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix all of the ingredients together and cook until the bitter melon is soft.
steps.description: When the eggs are partially set, stir them into the rest of the ingredients to incorporate them. Allow the mixture to saute until the bitter melon is completely soft and cooked through, which should take about 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Season the dish with salt and pepper.
steps.description: When the bitter melon is finished cooking, add salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Mix well to ensure that the dish is evenly seasoned.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture to a dish and serve with steamed rice.
steps.description: Spoon the mixture into a serving dish. For a traditional take, pair it with a side of rice, However, you can serve it with whatever your favorite side is.

steps.headline: Soak the bitter melon in salted water for several minutes.
steps.description: Place 2 medium pieces of bitter melon that’s been cleaned and sliced into a large bowl. Pour 2 to 3 cups (480 to 720 ml) of water over it to cover it, along with 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt. Let the melon soak for about 5 to 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a pan.
steps.description: Place a medium-size skillet on the stove over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of canola oil to the pan, and let it heat for 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Saute the garlic and onion until the onion is soft.
steps.description: When the oil is warmed, add 2 cloves of minced garlic and 1 medium chopped onion to the skillet. Allow the mixture to cook until the onions become translucent and softened, which should take about 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix in the ground beef and cook until it’s browned.
steps.description: When you’ve finished sauteing the onion and garlic, add 1 pound (454 g)  of ground beef to the skillet. Allow the meat to cook until it’s browned and cooked through, which should take about 5 minutes. If you prefer, you can substitute pork belly for the ground beef.

steps.headline: Stir in the soy sauce, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Once the ground beef is browned, add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of soy sauce and some salt and pepper to taste to the skillet. Mix well to ensure that the ingredients are fully combined.

steps.headline: Drain the bitter melon.
steps.description: Pour the water out of the bowl with the melon. Use paper towel or a clean kitchen towel to gently pat the melon dry.

steps.headline: Add the bitter melon and cook for several more minutes.
steps.description: Mix the drained melon into the skillet. Saute the mixture for about 5 more minutes to soften the melon.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture to a dish and serve with steamed rice.
steps.description: When the melon is soft, pour the mixture into a serving bowl. Pair it with the rice and serve while it’s still warm.

steps.headline: Coat the bitter melon with flour.
steps.description: Place 2 cups (250 g) of flour in a large bowl. Add 1 large bitter melon that’s been cleaned and cut into thin slices into the bowl. Toss the melon in the flour so all of the slices are evenly coated.

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a pan.
steps.description: Place a large skillet on the stove, and fill it with approximately (2 inches (5.1 cm) to 3 inches (7.6 cm) of canola oil. Allow the oil to heat on medium-high for about 5 minutes or until bubbles start to form along the edges. If you have a deep fryer, you can use it to fry the ampalaya instead of a skillet.

steps.headline: Add the melon and cook until golden brown.
steps.description: When the oil is hot, add some of the melon slices to the skillet and allow them to cook for 1 to 2 minutes so they brown on the first slide. Flip them over and fry them for another minute or until they’re golden brown on all sides. Make sure to place the bitter melon in a single layer in the pan. Depending on the size of your pan, you may need to fry the ampalaya in two batches or more.

steps.headline: Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate for drainage.
steps.description: When the bitter melon is finished frying, use a slotted spoon or tongs to lift it out of the pan. Place the slices on a plate lined with paper towel to absorb any excess oil still on the melon.

steps.headline: Season the melon with salt and pepper while still warm.
steps.description: The bitter melon absorbs the seasoning better when it’s hot, so don’t let it cool too much before seasoning it. Sprinkle some salt and pepper over the fried slices to your taste.

steps.headline: Transfer the bitter melon to a plate and serve while warm.
steps.description: Once the bitter melon is seasoned, it’s really to eat. Use a spatula to place it on a serving platter, and serve it alongside ketchup or mayonnaise for dipping.

text: Preparing Ginisang Ampalaya Soak the bitter melon in salted water for several minutes. Place 2 pieces of bitter melon that has been cleaned and cut into thin slices into a large bowl. Let the melon soak for about 5 minutes to help remove some of the bitterness. Squeeze the bitter melon in cheesecloth to drain. After the melon has soaked for several minutes, remove it from the water and place it on a piece of cheesecloth. Wrap the cheesecloth around it, and press on it to remove all of the excess moisture. Set the melon aside for the moment. Heat the oil in a pan. Place a large skillet on the stove, and heat it on on medium-high. Add 2 tablespoons (45 ml) of cooking oil such as canola, and let it heat in the pan for about 3 minutes. Cook the onion and garlic for several minutes. Add 1 tablespoon (8 g) of minced garlic and 1 large sliced onion to the heated pan. Allow the garlic and onion to saute until the garlic is golden brown and the onions are translucent, which should take 3 to 5 minutes. Add the tomatoes and saute until they’re softened. Mix 1 large tomato that’s been sliced into the pan with the onion and garlic. Let the tomatoes cook until they soften, which should take about 2 minutes. Stir in the bitter melon and cook it until tender. Once the tomato is softened, add the drained bitter melon to the pan. Saute it until it softens a bit, which should take approximately 3 minutes. Pour the eggs over the mixture and cook until partially done. After you’ve cooked the melon for a few minutes, add two beaten eggs to the pan over the melon, garlic, onion, and tomatoes. Let the mixture cook until the eggs are partially done, which should take about 2 to 3 minutes. Mix all of the ingredients together and cook until the bitter melon is soft. When the eggs are partially set, stir them into the rest of the ingredients to incorporate them. Allow the mixture to saute until the bitter melon is completely soft and cooked through, which should take about 3 to 5 minutes. Season the dish with salt and pepper. When the bitter melon is finished cooking, add salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Mix well to ensure that the dish is evenly seasoned. Transfer the mixture to a dish and serve with steamed rice. Spoon the mixture into a serving dish. For a traditional take, pair it with a side of rice, However, you can serve it with whatever your favorite side is. Making Ampalaya with Carne Soak the bitter melon in salted water for several minutes. Place 2 medium pieces of bitter melon that’s been cleaned and sliced into a large bowl. Pour 2 to 3 cups (480 to 720 ml) of water over it to cover it, along with 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt. Let the melon soak for about 5 to 10 minutes. Heat the oil in a pan. Place a medium-size skillet on the stove over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of canola oil to the pan, and let it heat for 3 to 5 minutes. Saute the garlic and onion until the onion is soft. When the oil is warmed, add 2 cloves of minced garlic and 1 medium chopped onion to the skillet. Allow the mixture to cook until the onions become translucent and softened, which should take about 3 minutes. Mix in the ground beef and cook until it’s browned. When you’ve finished sauteing the onion and garlic, add 1 pound (454 g)  of ground beef to the skillet. Allow the meat to cook until it’s browned and cooked through, which should take about 5 minutes. If you prefer, you can substitute pork belly for the ground beef. Stir in the soy sauce, salt, and pepper. Once the ground beef is browned, add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of soy sauce and some salt and pepper to taste to the skillet. Mix well to ensure that the ingredients are fully combined. Drain the bitter melon. Pour the water out of the bowl with the melon. Use paper towel or a clean kitchen towel to gently pat the melon dry. Add the bitter melon and cook for several more minutes. Mix the drained melon into the skillet. Saute the mixture for about 5 more minutes to soften the melon. Transfer the mixture to a dish and serve with steamed rice. When the melon is soft, pour the mixture into a serving bowl. Pair it with the rice and serve while it’s still warm. Making Crispy Fried Ampalaya Coat the bitter melon with flour. Place 2 cups (250 g) of flour in a large bowl. Add 1 large bitter melon that’s been cleaned and cut into thin slices into the bowl. Toss the melon in the flour so all of the slices are evenly coated. Heat the oil in a pan. Place a large skillet on the stove, and fill it with approximately (2 inches (5.1 cm) to 3 inches (7.6 cm) of canola oil. Allow the oil to heat on medium-high for about 5 minutes or until bubbles start to form along the edges. If you have a deep fryer, you can use it to fry the ampalaya instead of a skillet. Add the melon and cook until golden brown. When the oil is hot, add some of the melon slices to the skillet and allow them to cook for 1 to 2 minutes so they brown on the first slide. Flip them over and fry them for another minute or until they’re golden brown on all sides. Make sure to place the bitter melon in a single layer in the pan. Depending on the size of your pan, you may need to fry the ampalaya in two batches or more. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate for drainage. When the bitter melon is finished frying, use a slotted spoon or tongs to lift it out of the pan. Place the slices on a plate lined with paper towel to absorb any excess oil still on the melon. Season the melon with salt and pepper while still warm. The bitter melon absorbs the seasoning better when it’s hot, so don’t let it cool too much before seasoning it. Sprinkle some salt and pepper over the fried slices to your taste. Transfer the bitter melon to a plate and serve while warm. Once the bitter melon is seasoned, it’s really to eat. Use a spatula to place it on a serving platter, and serve it alongside ketchup or mayonnaise for dipping.
